title: The Thing About Things
synopsis: Three stories about the strange power inanimate objects can hold over us.

acts.title: Prologue
acts.summary: Nunzio gets caught in a kind of servile relationship—with a scooter.

acts.title: Act One: A Rock and a Hard Place
acts.summary: Ted was six when he first picked up a rock from the Petrified Forest National Park. Nearly 50 years later, he really wishes he hadn’t. Aviva DeKornfeld talked to him. We first heard about this story from Ryan Thompson’s book Bad Luck, Hot Rocks .

acts.title: Act Two: A Few Hundred of My Favorite Things
acts.summary: Heavyweight host Jonathan Goldstein leaps in to help a family, who are not entirely sure they want or need his help, get rid of their stuff. This story originally aired on the Heavyweight podcast.

title: This Is the Case of Henry Dee
synopsis: Thirteen parole board members decide whether or not one man should be released from prison.

acts.title: Prologue
acts.summary: Henry Dee has been locked up for most of his life, nearly 50 years. Now, he’s up for parole. Reporter Ben Austen tells the story.

title: My Other Self
synopsis: What happens when people create alternate versions of themselves and release them into the wild?

acts.title: Prologue
acts.summary: Host Ira Glass talks about a recent experience being interviewed and the realization that he was being asked about another version of himself.

acts.title: Act One: Me and My Shadow
acts.summary: Reporter Evan Ratliff creates an AI version of himself and then sets it loose on the world. This story was adapted from Evan's podcast, Shell Game .

acts.title: Act Two: Papa Was a Trolling Stone
acts.summary: Emmanuel Dzotsi explores the phenomenon of people lying on first dates to project a better version of themselves. Plus, he gets into a very personal example from his own life.

title: Harold
synopsis: When Zohran Mamdani won the primary race for New York mayor, the Democratic establishment's lukewarm response echoed the treatment of another charismatic, unconventional candidate decades earlier. This week, we bring you the story of Harold Washington, the greatest politician you've probably never heard of, and the backlash that ensued when he became Chicago's first Black mayor.

acts.title: Prologue
acts.summary: As New York City’s Democratic establishment attempts to resist the candidacy of Zohran Mamdani, we look back at another mayoral candidate who upset the established political machine.

acts.title: Act One: Yesterday
acts.summary: A history of the brief mayoral career of Harold Washington and its lessons for Black and white America, as told by people close to him. Harold Washington died on November 25, 1987.  This show was first broadcast ten years later, in 1997.

acts.title: Act Two: The Present and the Future
acts.summary: Ira revisits interviews with Chicago voters from the 1997 and 2007 rebroadcasts of this episode. In 1997, ten years after Harold Washington’s death, not much had changed in Chicago. By 2007, attitudes had begun to shift slowly, and another Black politician from Chicago was on the rise — Barack Obama. Ira also speaks to David Axelrod, an advisor to both Harold Washington and Barack Obama. Song: “Chicago” sung by Harold Washington at his second inauguration

title: Winners
synopsis: America loves winners—now more than ever. But how do you get to a win in 2025 America? We watch someone trying to score a win in a game whose rules are being made up as she plays.

acts.title: Prologue
acts.summary: Ira talks to producer Diane Wu about an informal survey she’s done with the staff of This American Life about a phrase Ira says a lot that includes the word “winners.”

acts.title: Act One: Winners Welcome
acts.summary: Two people see one of President Trump’s first executive orders and get excited, and then get to work.

acts.title: Act Two: Winners Welcome, cont’d
acts.summary: We follow the progress of one woman as she builds up, from scratch, a whole movement based on one of Trump’s executive orders.

title: The Hand That Rocks The Gavel
synopsis: A group of immigration judges, who almost never speak to the press, describes the dismantling of our immigration court system from the inside.

acts.title: Prologue
acts.summary: Zoe Chace gives an eyewitness account of what has been happening at 26 Federal Plaza, an immigration courthouse in New York City.

acts.title: Act One: Act One
acts.summary: The judges walk us through how different their jobs have become in just the past few months, because of sweeping policy changes by Trump’s Department of Justice.

acts.title: Act Two: Act Two
acts.summary: It gets extremely personal for the judges. Also, the story of one person who got pushed through the new immigration court system this summer.

title: College Disorientation
synopsis: Things are different on college campuses this year. We see inside the drama, with students and staff.

image.credit: Black Student Union at The University of Utah

acts.title: Prologue
acts.summary: We go to orientation at Arizona State University and meet international students who are trying to make friends.

acts.title: Act One: My Black President
acts.summary: The president of the Black Student Union at the University of Utah fights to keep the B in BSU.

acts.title: Act Two: The Art of the Deal
acts.summary: A definition of antisemitism, canceled classes, and angry professors at Columbia University.
